Request for Proposals for Solar Power Purchase Agreement 

 

Notice is hereby given that pursuant to the Local Public Contracts Law competitive contracting process, N.J.S.A.

Terry Youmans

1. Introduction 
 
The Hazlet Township Public School District Board of Education (“BOE”) will accept proposals (RFP) for the 
installation of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on Hazlet Township Public School District property The BOE 
awarded a contract to DCO Energy, LLC (“DCO”) as its energy consultant to solicit and evaluate solar PPA bids. 
 
The BOE will accept proposals from solar financier/developers through this request for proposals (“RFP”) 
for the installation of a solar photovoltaic system (“PV System”) to be installed at the following  BOE schools: 
(1) Beers Street Elementary Schools, (2) Middle Road Elementary School, (3) Cove Road Elementary 
School, (4) Sycamore Drive Early Childhood Learning Center (hereinafter, sometimes, referred to as the 
“Base Schools”).   All proposers shall provide proposals which include the Base Schools. In addition, 
proposers may include an alternate offer in their submittal which includes the Base Schools as well as any 
or all of the following school:  (1) Raritan Valley School (hereinafter, sometimes, referred to as the “Alternate 
Offer School”).  The PV System shall be roof mounted systems.  Roof work may be required in some areas 
and the cost of same shall be included as a PPA price adder for the installation of the PV System to be 
performed by and paid for by the awarded proposer of this RFP.   
 
Included in this RFP is information about the BOE planned solar project, to aid each respondent with its 
Proposal.  The BOE will evaluate and select a company based upon the received Proposals in order to 
move forward with the final development and installation of the PV System (hereinafter sometimes referred to 
as the “Solar Project”). 

 
The BOE’s goals for this Solar Project are to: 

 Maximize savings through a lower electric rate provided by a PPA (as defined in this RFP); 
 Offset as much of the BOE’s  electric load as possible; 
 Inspire sustainability within the community;  
 Provide a safe installation of the Solar Project for firefighters and first responders in the event of 

emergency; and, 
 District is interested in remote-net-metering options to maximize solar generation while 

minimizing impacted roof areas. 

The BOE is requesting proposed PPA rates based upon the information contained in this Proposal. 
Providers submitting Proposals (“Proposers”) must have the ability to offer PPA financing. Given the 
multiple facets that constitute a solar development project, multiple parties may jointly submit Proposals in 
partnership. Proposals will be evaluated based on the qualifications of the Provider, scope of services to be 
provided, and PPA financing terms offered (consistent with the form of PPA attached hereto as Schedule 1). 
Providers should use this RFP as a guide for organizing their Proposal but are encouraged to expand upon, 
refine, or suggest alternative approaches based on previous experience with similar projects.  The Proposal 
shall be in accordance with the RFP Requirements and fully comply with the requirements of the 
Department of Energy (“DOE”), Division of Consumer Affairs (“DCA”), Public School Contracts Law, Office 
of Clean Energy Requirements for renewable energy systems and the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities 
(“BPU”).  

The issuance of this RFP is not intended to, and shall not be construed to, commit the BOE to execute any 
agreement. Neither the BOE, nor any of its consultants, shall be liable for any claims or damages resulting 
from the solicitation or receipt of Proposals in response to this RFP, nor will there be any reimbursement to 
Proposers for the cost of preparing the Proposal or for participating in the RFP process. By submitting a 
Proposal in response to this RFP, the Proposers accept and consent to the procurement process selected

2. Scope of Services to be Provided 
The Proposer will provide fully managed PV development services that include, but are not limited to, site 
assessment; Solar Project design; financing; and securing the necessary labor, services, equipment, 
funding, permits and approvals to develop fully operational Solar Project at each potential site described in 
Appendix A, (each a “Project Site”); will commission, monitor, operate, and maintain the Solar Project after 
installation for Projects Sites; and will establish and maintain construction standards, safety, and quality 
control throughout the work on the Solar Project.  The BOE intends to enter into individual PPAs to purchase 
electricity generated at each Project Site for a term of fifteen (15) years with the awarded Proposer (the 
“Contract Term”).   

Services to be provided by the Proposer include:  

Site Assessment and Proposal 

The Proposer will conduct an assessment of each Project Site within the BOE (as included in Appendix A), 
including an analysis of the impact of shading, tilt, and orientation on annual electricity production, and note 
any electrical, mechanical or structural considerations. 

The Proposer will submit a Proposal including: 

 kW DC generating capacity, project layout, configuration, azimuth, tilt angle, derate factor, and 
projected degradation rate of proposed PV System. 

 Projected annual energy generation in kWh for the full period of the PPA. 
 Projected annual PPA costs for the full period of the PPA. 
 Proposed PPA rate, annual escalation not to exceed two percent (2%) per year, if any, and rate 

increase for removal and re-installation of panels, if required during the term of the PPA. 
 Evaluation of the condition of the roofs of the schools. 

 

PPA Financing 

The BOE is seeking third-party ownership, financing and maintenance agreement with the Proposer. 
Proposers should indicate whether or not guaranteed financing is available, who will be funding the Solar 
Project, and who will own the Solar Project. 

 

Utility Interconnect 

As part of this Proposal process, Proposers shall verify with the BOE’s electric utility company Jersey 
Central Power & Light (“JCP&L”), whether the proposed site is on a restricted circuit and can host the 
proposed array. The selected Proposer will be responsible, at its own expense, for securing all required 
permits (not limited to but including: building, construction, electrical, environmental, and zoning) and 
interconnection requirements with JCP&L. The BOE has submitted interconnection applications for all five 
(5) proposed sites; the findings from these applications will be shared with Proposers pending JCP&L’s 
approval. The selected Proposer will also be responsible for scheduling and passing all jurisdictional and 
utility inspections. 

 

New Jersey Department of Education and Local Planning Board 

The Proposer will provide signed and sealed drawings and cost estimates for the Solar Project sufficient 
for the BOE’s architect to submit the projects to the New Jersey Department of Education Office of School 
Facilities and to the local Planning Board, including but not limited to a structural engineering report 
certifying that the roof will be able to easily support the weight of any equipment installed during the course 
of the solar project.  The Proposer shall commit to being present for public hearings before the Planning 
Board meeting to discuss the Solar Project, if required. 



4

Environmental Permitting 

The selected Proposer will be responsible for securing all environmental permits. 

Geotechnical Surveys 

The selected Provider will be responsible for all surveys required to quantify geotechnical conditions.  

Design and Installation 

The installations will be carried out by the selected Proposer in conformance with all applicable laws and codes, 
interconnection requirements, and established industry practices and will be completed as quickly and with 
as little disruption as reasonably possible.  

Proposer shall provide design documents with the following minimum information: 

 Timeline/Project Schedule
 Solar Project description
 Equipment details and description
 Layout of installation
 Layout of equipment
 Selection of key equipment
 Specifications for equipment procurement and installation
 All engineering associated with structural work, and/or mounting details.
 Performance of equipment components, and subsystems
 Electrical grid interconnection requirements
 Controls, monitors, and instrumentation
 Solar Project performance monitoring
 Any other drawing or specification information required to secure a building and/or electrical

permit

Proposer shall identify an appropriate location for the solar PV inverter equipment and its 
related components and any required environmental control systems that will meet the following criteria: 

 Ease of maintenance and monitoring
 Efficient operation
 Low operating losses
 Secured location and hardware
 Compatibility with existing facilities
 Avoidance of flood-prone areas
 Visual harmony
 Approved firefighters’ and any other code safety requirements

Each Proposer shall provide three (3) sets of as-built drawings and one (1) electronic USB copy to 
the BOE. 

Operation, Maintenance and Monitoring 

The selected Proposer will be responsible for the operation, maintenance, and monitoring of the Solar 
Project at each Project Site under the PPA. The selected Proposer will make accessible to the BOE in an 
online interface showing instantaneous and cumulative energy production of each PV system deployed at 
each Project Site that can be used for monitoring purposes. Historical cumulative energy production shall

#95039113.1 

be available in monthly increments for historical purposes. 

Annual (or as needed) on-site Solar Project inspections, including: 
 

 Solar Project testing (operating current of each electrical string) 
 Routine preventive maintenance 
 Repair and/or replacement of defective parts (including equipment and labor) 
 Ongoing regular maintenance (more than annual) of any ground areas beneath any ground-

mount systems, if applicable. 
 

Solar Project performance monitoring and historical data access for the BOE via secure website. Data 
should include: 

 
 Solar Project energy and power production 
 Ambient temperature 
 Wind speed  

 
Communication 
The selected Proposer will be required to designate a specific staff member who will serve as the primary 
point of contact for the BOE during the development and construction of the Solar Project (“Solar Project 
Period”). The selected Proposer will interface directly with the BOE. The selected Proposer will provide 
regular progress updates during the Solar Project Period. The selected Proposer will be expected to be 
responsive and prompt in communications with  the BOE, when necessary.  The BOE will designate a 
specific staff member to facilitate communication and coordination between the selected Proposer and the 
BOE. 
 
 
Fire Safety 
The selected Proposer will be required to include a “Firefighters Safety Procedure” manual in case of the event 
of a fire occurring with rooftop solar panels installed. It is the responsibility of the Proposer to receive 
approval(s) by the single and/or multiple Jurisdiction Holding Authority (JHA) for an acceptable “Firefighters 
Safety Procedure”. 
 
 
Solar Project Removal 
 
The awarded Proposer shall bear the sole cost and responsibility of removing the Solar Project at the end 
of the service term should the BOE, in its sole discretion, opt not to purchase the Solar Project.  The 
awarded Proposer shall remove the Solar Project within ninety (90) days of the end of the service term and 
shall repair any damage caused in connection with such removal.  
 
 
Incentives 
 
The BOE makes no representations to the availability of incentives. The awarded Proposer is responsible 
for identifying, designing the project to meet the requirements, and attaining all incentives available. The 
BOE will not accept contingent Proposals, including Proposals or proposed PPA prices that are contingent 
on specific incentive programs and amounts. 
 
 
Minimum Electricity Output Requirement  
 
The awarded Proposer shall guarantee a minimum energy output each year, which shall be 90% of the 
aggregate projected annual output based on the solar capacity and estimation of electricity output based 
on the design, and a 0.5% per year degradation rate. The electricity output requirement shall be calculated 
annually based on the total production to date versus the minimum output projection to date. The resulting 



 

6 
#95039113.1 

credit to the BOE, if applicable, will be calculated based on the differential of actual versus projected output 
multiplied by the calculated difference between the utility rate charged to the BOE minus the PPA rate for 
that year of the term. If the actual output is higher than the minimum electricity output requirement, then no 
payment or credit is required. 
 
 
Removal and Replacement of Solar Project for Roofing Repairs by Others After Installation of Solar Project 
 
In the event that roofing repairs are required at any of the buildings at the project site(s) after the installation 
of the Solar Project, the BOE may direct the awarded Proposer to remove and replace the affected portion 
of the Solar Project. The costs to remove and replace the affected portion of the Solar Project will be the 
responsibility of the awarded Proposer.  Prior to the removal and replacement, the costs will be reported to 
the BOE for approval, which approval shall not be unreasonable withheld. So long as awarded Proposer 
did not cause the damage to the roof that necessitated the repairs, the BOE shall reimburse awarded 
Proposer for removal and replacement of the affected portion of the Solar Project as follows: for the first 
ten (10) years of the Contract Term, as a cash payment of the actual costs or as an adjustment in the solar 
PPA rate for the remainder of the Contract Term as determined by awarded Proposer and the BOE; and, 
after the first ten years of the Contract Term as a cash payment of actual costs. Any cash payment of actual 
costs as required by this section shall be made within sixty (60) days of awarded Proposer’s notice to the 
BOE of the actual costs and completion of the work. 
 
 
Temporary Shutdown of the Solar Facility 
 
The BOE will not cause any of the schools in the Solar Project to shut down temporarily, unless in the case 
of emergency or in a Force Majeure Event for more than a total of ten (10) days in any two (2) consecutive 
contract years, whether scheduled or as a result of an emergency, act or omission caused by the BOE (a 
“Temporary Shutdown”).  Further, the BOE shall make best efforts not to schedule a Temporary Shutdown 
during the Solar Project’s peak production months of April through August. The BOE will communicate to 
the awarded Proposer the commencement date and expected duration of any such Temporary Shutdown 
as far in advance of the commencement of the Temporary Shutdown as practicable.  In the event the 
duration of the Temporary Shutdown is in excess of ten (10) days in any two (2) consecutive contract years, 
the BOE shall pay to the awarded Proposer an  amount equal to the following: (i) the reasonable cost to 
remove and re-install or shutdown and reinitiate the Solar Project or portion of the Solar Project; (ii) the 
cost, if any, of lost solar energy production during the period of Temporary Shutdown in excess of the ten 
(10) days in any two (2) consecutive contract years at the PPA Price then in effect; and (iii) an amount 
attributable to any lost solar renewable energy credits, if any, calculated at the awarded Proposer’s actual 
out-or-pocket loss in excess of the ten (10) days in any two (2) consecutive contract years.  If the shut down 
is for less than ten (10) days in any consecutive two (2) year period for any of the solar facilities, then the 
BOE shall only be responsible for the cost to remove and reinstall the solar panels. 
 
 
Commercial Operation Date – Guaranteed Completion Date 
 
Proposer shall provide a Commercial Operation Date and Guaranteed Completion Date for each of the 
Base Schools and the Alternate Offer School, if applicable.  In the event the Commercial Operation Date 
has not been achieved by the Guaranteed Completion Date for any school, the awarded Proposer shall be 
liable for delay liquidated damages of $250.00 per day for each day of unexcused delay until the 
Commercial Operation Date is achieved.  The Commercial Operation Date will commence after: (i) no less 
than eighty percent (80%) of the nameplate capacity has been installed; and (ii) the awarded Proposer has 
acquired all permits necessary to authorize the production, sale and delivery of energy in the intended 
amounts hereunder; and (iii) the awarded Proposer gives the BOE written notice that the Solar Project is 
mechanically complete and has been approved for interconnected operation by the applicable utility and 
capable of providing energy to the awarded Proposers meter at each respective school. 
 
 



 

7 
#95039113.1 

 
 
Warranties 
 
The Proposer shall clearly describe all warranties offered in the Proposal which shall include, but not be 
limited to, the PV System and roof, if applicable. With respect to the PV System, the Proposer shall provide 
equipment that meets or exceeds these minimum standards: (a) photovoltaic panels that have an expected 
useful life of no less than a twenty five (25) year performance warranty with a minimum  production capacity 
of 90% for ten (10) years from the Commercial Operating Date, and, thereafter,  the panels are warranted 
by the manufacturer to operate at a capacity of at least 80% of their original rated operational capacity as 
specified by such manufacturer; (b) an inverter with no less than a fifteen (15) year product warranty; (c) a 
racking/monitoring system with no less than a ten (10) year product warranty; and (d) a material and 
workmanship warranty of ten (10) years.  All such warranty documents shall be attached to the PPA as an 
exhibit.  Such warranties shall be assignable to the BOE on termination of the PPA. 
 
Attached hereto for information and reference are the following Attachments relating to the sites where 
solar is to be proposed: 
 
* Attachment A – Roof Warranty Status 
* Attachment B – Roof IR Reports 
 
 
BOE Purchase Option 
 
The BOE shall have the option at the end of the Contract Term, to purchase the Solar Project at the fair 
market value thereof. 
 
 
Professional Services Payment 
 
The awarded Proposer shall make a payment of $30,000 to the BOE immediately upon the execution of 
the PPA as a reimbursement of the costs incurred by the BOE for professional service fees required in the 
issuance of a competitive solicitation pursuant to Public School Contract Law for the agreement. 
 
 
Protect Solar Access 
 
The BOE will agree to take reasonable efforts to prevent others from conducting activities at the Solar 
Projects  which cause shading of the PV System. The BOE shall be responsible for all costs concerning 
trimming, pruning, topping or otherwise controlling the growth of any tree, shrub, plant or other vegetation 
planted after the Effective Date of the PPA to prevent obstruction of sunlight to the PV System.  The 
awarded Proposer shall be responsible at its cost for tree trimming, pruning, topping of all trees, shrubs and 
plants present as of the Effective Date after obtaining the BOE’s approval.  In addition to the foregoing, 
during the design and installation of the Solar Energy System, the awarded Proposer shall identify all trees, 
shrubs, plants or other vegetation which will be trimmed or removed; which shall be subject to the consent 
of the BOE. 
 
 
Electrical Interconnections 
 
The awarded Proposer shall supply and install all equipment required to interconnect the Solar Project to 
the utility electric distribution system as net-metered solar energy systems. The awarded Proposer shall 
fulfill all applications, studies, and testing procedures to complete the interconnection process. Except as 
otherwise provided herein below, all costs associated with utility interconnection shall be borne by the 
awarded Proposer. 
 



 

8 
#95039113.1 

If the electric distribution company interconnection review concludes that interconnection can only be 
completed with upgrades, the awarded Proposer shall bear the cost of $0.10/Watt dc for for these 
improvements at each Solar Project.  If the utility required upgrades are in excess of $0.10/Watt dc to gain 
interconnection approval for any one Solar Project, then the awarded Proposer shall advise the BOE and 
the BOE shall have the option to remove that Solar Project from the PPA contract without penalty and, 
without any further obligation, proceed with the Solar Project or reimburse the Proposer for the excess cost 
above the allowance. Such option must be exercised prior to the commencement of the physical 
construction of the Solar Project. 
 
 
Electric Service Interruptions 
 
The awarded Proposer must coordinate all interruptions of the BOE’s electric service required for the 
installation, interconnection, commissioning, startup, and maintenance of the Solar Project’s. This 
interruption shall not be performed during the BOE’s normal working days/hours.  Proposers are required 
to disclose in this proposal, the physical and operational limitations including the minimum number of hours 
to be allocated to system shutdown to afford the BOE access to its facilities. 
 

Early Termination Right 

The PPA shall provide that the awarded Proposer may terminate the PPA at any time prior to Commercial 
Operation Date, on thirty (30) days written notice to the BOE, without further liability except as provided 
herein, if the awarded Proposer (a) determines that the Solar Project cannot be built as planned or that its 
construction and operation would not be economically viable for the awarded Proposer; or, (b) the awarded 
Proposer is unable, after diligent efforts, to obtain or maintain required approvals from all applicable 
Governmental authorities for the installation and operation of the Solar Project; and (c) the awarded 
Proposer exercises such right to terminate no later than one hundred eighty (180) days from the full 
execution of the PPA. If the awarded Proposer exercises its early termination right as provided herein, the 
awarded Proposer shall reimburse the BOE for any reasonable, documented costs incurred or committed 
and to be incurred by the BOE in connection with the planned installation of the Solar Project, remove at 
its own expense any portion of the Solar Project that has been already installed, and repair at its own 
expense the premises to its pre-installation condition. The awarded Proposer shall be solely responsible 
for any and all costs and damages associated with the removal of the Solar Project under this paragraph. 

 

Permitted Hours for Construction. 

Construction activities shall adhere to all of the following requirements, as well as any additional 
requirements directed by the BOE or its representatives to ensure safety and normal operations of the 
facilities: 

 
 All work to be performed on this project shall be in accordance with BOE approval or other 

such times as may be designated by the BOE and local ordinances. 
 The contractor is responsible to pay for custodial time if they need to work outside the 

designated work hours to meet the project schedule.  
 The contractor cannot work within the school buildings at any time without prior approval 

from the BOE. 
 All demolition and construction noise and dust to be limited inside the building during hours

### **Project Specifications and Contractor Expectations**  

#### **Project Overview**  
The **Hazlet Township Public School District** is seeking proposals for the installation of **solar photovoltaic (PV) systems** under a **Power Purchase Agreement (PPA)**. The system will be **roof-mounted** on several school buildings within the district.

#### **Project Scope**
- Installation of **solar PV systems** at:
  1. **Beers Street Elementary School**
  2. **Middle Road Elementary School**
  3. **Cove Road Elementary School**
  4. **Sycamore Drive Early Childhood Learning Center**
  - **Optional:** **Raritan Valley Elementary School** may be included in an **alternate proposal**.

- **15-year PPA** for the purchase of electricity generated by the system.
- The contractor is **responsible for financing** and maintaining the system.
- **Roof work** may be required and must be included as a **PPA price adder**.
- **Remote net-metering** options are of interest to the district.

#### **Key Responsibilities of the Contractor**
1. **Site Assessment & Proposal Submission**
   - Conduct a **shading, tilt, and orientation analysis**.
   - Evaluate **electrical, mechanical, and structural conditions**.
   - Submit a proposal with **projected energy generation, financing terms, and PPA rate escalation (max 2% per year).**

2. **Design & Installation**
   - Develop system designs including **equipment selection, electrical interconnection, and mounting details**.
   - Ensure compliance with **New Jersey Department of Education (NJDOE), local planning boards, and other regulatory agencies**.
   - Obtain all **permits, approvals, and interconnection agreements**.
   - Provide **construction plans, safety measures, and fire department approvals**.

3. **Operations, Maintenance & Monitoring**
   - Maintain and operate the system for the **entire PPA term**.
   - Provide an **online monitoring platform** for energy production tracking.
   - Conduct **annual inspections, preventive maintenance, and necessary repairs**.
   - Guarantee **minimum output** of **90%** of projected energy generation.

4. **Roof Work & Structural Considerations**
   - Evaluate **roof conditions** before installation.
   - Ensure **solar installation does not void roof warranties**.
   - Be responsible for **removal and reinstallation costs** if roofing repairs are needed during the contract term.

5. **Project Timelines & Penalties**
   - Must meet a **guaranteed completion date**.
   - Delays beyond the agreed-upon **Commercial Operation Date** will result in **$250/day penalties**.

6. **Financial & Legal Commitments**
   - **No upfront costs** for the school district.
   - Must provide a **performance bond** and a **surety certificate**.
   - Responsible for securing **incentives and financing** (not contingent on incentives).
   - A **$30,000 professional services reimbursement** to the district upon contract execution.

7. **Decommissioning & Removal**
   - At the end of the **PPA term**, the school district may **purchase the system** at fair market value or request **removal** at the contractor’s expense.

#### **Key Deadlines**
- **Pre-Proposal Meeting & Site Visit:** February 11, 2025  
- **Questions Due:** February 18, 2025  
- **Proposals Due:** March 6, 2025  
- **Contract Approval:** March 17, 2025  
- **Execution of PPA:** April 25, 2025  
- **Expected Commercial Operation Date:** 270 days after Notice to Proceed

### **Proposal Evaluation Criteria for the Hazlet Township Public School District Solar PPA Project**
Proposals will be evaluated on a **100-point scale** based on the following criteria:

---

### **1. Proposer Profile and Qualifications – 25 Points**
- Experience in **solar PV system development**, especially in **New Jersey public sector projects**.
- Number of completed **commercial and industrial PV projects** in the past 5 years.
- Track record in **financing PPA projects**.
- References from at least **three similar projects**, preferably with **municipalities or schools**.
- List of **key personnel** involved in the project and their relevant experience.
- Financial stability, bonding capacity, and **proof of insurance**.
- Compliance with **New Jersey licensing, registrations, and certifications**.

---

### **2. Scope of Services and Project Execution Plan – 25 Points**
- **Detailed project schedule** outlining:
  - **Site evaluation**
  - **Permitting and approvals**
  - **Design and construction**
  - **Commercial Operation Date**
- **Design approach**, including:
  - Solar panel layout
  - Electrical interconnection details
  - Structural assessments and roof considerations
- **Operation and maintenance (O&M) strategy**, including:
  - Preventative maintenance plans
  - System monitoring approach
  - Remote access capabilities for performance tracking
- **Fire safety and emergency response procedures**.
- **Permitting and interconnection expediting plan** to minimize delays.

---

### **3. Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) Financing Terms – 45 Points**
- **Year 1 PPA price per kWh** (lower price is better).
- **Annual escalation rate**, with a maximum of **2% per year**.
- Additional costs:
  - **Roof work** cost impact on PPA pricing.
  - Interconnection cost considerations.
- **Terms of ownership** (who owns the system during and after the PPA term).
- Proposal should ensure that the **BOE has no financial obligations** beyond the agreed PPA rate.

---

### **4. Educational Value – 5 Points**
- Proposer’s ability to **integrate solar education** into the school district’s curriculum.
- Potential to provide:
  - **Lesson plans on solar energy and sustainability**.
  - **Workshops, site tours, or interactive programs**.
  - **Real-time energy monitoring dashboard for students**.

---

### **5. Compliance & Documentation – Pass/Fail**
- Proposal must include:
  - Required forms (Statement of Ownership, Non-Collusion Affidavit, Consent of Surety, etc.).
  - Compliance with **affirmative action and equal employment laws**.
  - Proof of **New Jersey business registration and contractor licenses**.
  - Acknowledgment of **addenda and disclosures**.

---

### **Final Selection Process**
- Proposals will be reviewed based on the above criteria.
- The district may request **clarifications or additional information**.
- **Interviews** may be scheduled with shortlisted proposers.
- Final selection is at the **sole discretion of the BOE**.

Yes, **prevailing wage is required** for this project.

The **Hazlet Township Public School District** has specified that proposers must comply with the **Public Works Contractor Registration Act (P.L. 1999, c.238)**. This means:
- Contractors and their **subcontractors** must be **registered with the New Jersey Department of Labor**.
- Workers on the project must be paid **prevailing wage rates**, as per **New Jersey’s prevailing wage laws (N.J.S.A. 34:11-56.25 et seq.)**.

Additionally, the awarded proposer must provide:
- **Certified payroll records** to ensure compliance.
- Proper classification of workers based on the **New Jersey Department of Labor wage determinations**.

This requirement is standard for **public projects in New Jersey**, especially those involving school districts, to ensure fair compensation for laborers.

Yes, there are several **non-standard requirements** in the **Hazlet Township Public School District Solar PPA RFP** that go beyond typical solar PPA agreements. Here are the key ones:  

---

### **1. Roof Work Cost Must Be Included in PPA Price Adder**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The awarded contractor must evaluate and potentially **fund roof work** as part of the PPA.
  - Costs for **roof repairs or replacements** required for solar installation **must be included as a price adder** to the PPA rate.  
  - The district will evaluate whether to **extend the roof warranty through the life of the PPA** (specifically for **Raritan Valley Elementary School**).  

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Typically, school districts handle roof maintenance separately from solar projects.
  - Here, the contractor is responsible for assessing the **roof conditions** and ensuring that solar installation **does not void warranties**.

---

### **2. Mandatory Payment to BOE for Professional Services ($30,000)**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The awarded contractor must **pay $30,000 to the BOE** upon execution of the PPA.  
  - This serves as a **reimbursement** for the district’s legal, consulting, and procurement costs.  

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Most PPAs do not require the contractor to **directly reimburse the school district** for procurement-related expenses.

---

### **3. Guaranteed Minimum Electricity Output (90%)**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The contractor must **guarantee that the system produces at least 90%** of the projected annual energy output.
  - If production falls below this, the contractor **must compensate the district** for the shortfall.  

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Many PPAs include performance guarantees, but **90% is a high threshold**.
  - The contract also includes **specific degradation rates (0.5% per year)**, which the contractor must factor into system design.

---

### **4. Removal & Reinstallation Costs for Roofing Repairs**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - If **roofing repairs** are needed during the contract term, the contractor must **remove and reinstall the solar panels at their own cost**.
  - If the repair is unrelated to solar damage, the district will **reimburse the contractor** for costs **only after 10 years** into the contract.
  - Reimbursements for removals in **years 1–10** can be structured as either:
    - A **cash payment** of the actual costs.
    - An **adjustment to the PPA rate**.  

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Many PPAs place full removal/reinstallation responsibility **on the system owner (contractor)** for the **entire contract term**.
  - Here, the BOE is offering **some reimbursement**, but only after the first 10 years.

---

### **5. Temporary Shutdown Restrictions & Penalties**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The BOE **cannot shut down the solar system** for more than **10 days within two consecutive years** (except in emergencies).
  - If the shutdown exceeds this limit, the **BOE must compensate the contractor** for:
    1. **Lost solar production** (PPA rate).
    2. **Lost SREC revenue** (contractor’s out-of-pocket loss).
    3. **Any costs related to system shutdown and reactivation**.

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Most PPAs allow the host site to perform maintenance or make necessary changes **without financial penalties**.
  - This contract **financially protects the contractor** from revenue loss due to unexpected downtime.

---

### **6. Firefighter Safety Plan Approval Required**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The contractor **must create a Firefighter Safety Procedure Manual**.
  - The manual **must be approved by local fire safety authorities** before installation begins.

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Fire safety is always a consideration, but requiring a **custom manual approved before installation** is an additional step.

---

### **7. BOE Can Cancel a Project Site if Interconnection Costs Exceed $0.10/Watt**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - If utility-required interconnection upgrades exceed **$0.10/Watt DC**, the BOE has the right to **remove that site from the PPA**.
  - This decision must be made **before construction begins**.

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Many PPAs lock in the full site list **before interconnection costs are finalized**.
  - This provision gives the district **financial control to drop a site** if unexpected costs arise.

---

### **8. Proposer Must Be Present for Public Planning Board Hearings**  
- **Unique Requirement:**  
  - The contractor must attend **public hearings before the Planning Board** to present and answer questions about the solar project.

- **Why It's Non-Standard:**  
  - Most PPAs do not require the **solar provider to participate in public hearings**.
  - This adds a **public relations component** to the contractor’s role.

---

### **Summary of Non-Standard Requirements**
| Requirement | What Makes It Non-Standard? |
|------------|-----------------------------|
| **Roof work cost included in PPA** | Contractor must assess and possibly **fund roof repairs**. |
| **$30,000 payment to BOE** | Contractor must **reimburse the district** for procurement costs. |
| **90% minimum energy guarantee** | High performance threshold with **monetary penalties**. |
| **Solar removal & reinstallation policy** | BOE **partially reimburses** contractor after 10 years. |
| **Limits on system shutdown** | BOE must **pay contractor for lost energy** if shutdown exceeds 10 days. |
| **Fire safety plan approval required** | Firefighter plan **must be pre-approved** before installation. |
| **BOE can cancel a site over interconnection costs** | If costs exceed **$0.10/Watt**, the district can **remove that site**. |
| **Contractor must attend public hearings** | Requires contractor to **answer public questions** before the Planning Board. |

---

### **Final Thoughts**
These provisions **increase financial risks for the contractor** but **protect the district** from cost overruns. If you’re bidding, you’ll need to:
- **Carefully assess roof conditions** before finalizing your proposal.
- **Plan for compliance costs**, especially around prevailing wage, interconnection, and fire safety.
- **Price in the risk** of system removal and reinstallation if roofing work is needed.
